newsitem.title: FRANCE: French centre-right holds slim lead in seats - poll.
newsitem.headline: French centre-right holds slim lead in seats - poll.

text.p: Following are the results of an opinion poll of voters' intentions published on Monday ahead of the May 25/June 1 French parliamentary election.
The poll of 958 adults aged 18 and over was conducted by BVA between April 30 and May 3 for Europe 1 radio, France 2 television and French weekly Paris Match:

The projection in seats covers the 555 constituencies in metropolitan France, not the 22 seats in overseas departments and territories, most of which were held in the outgoing assembly by supporters of the centre-right government.
BVA said 17 percent of those polled did not say how they would vote. Of those who expressed a preference, 37 percent said they could still change their minds.

The poll also showed that while voters appeared evenly split on which bloc they hope will win the election - 39 percent for the left and 40 percent for the ruling coalition - only 16 percent thought the left would actually win. Forty-nine percent said they expected the centre-right to retain power.
Fifty-eight percent of those polled did not think the Socialist party had an alternative policy to offer France.
